article.title: Two-photon quantum Rabi model with superconducting circuits

multiple_choice_question.text: Which component in the circuit shown in Figure 1 introduces the nonlinearity required for intrinsic two-photon interactions?
In Figure 2, what key difference is observed in the energy spectrum between the standard one-photon and the two-photon QRM for resonant interactions?
choices: Vacuum Rabi splitting is absent in the two-photon QRM.
Energy levels are equally spaced in the two-photon QRM.
The first excited state in the two-photon QRM has no atomic excitation.
The ground state energy is different for the two models.

multiple_choice_question.text: What significant difference does Figure 3 illustrate in the cavity transmission properties when comparing the one-photon and two-photon QRMs under weak coherent cavity driving?
choices: The two-photon QRM shows a double peak structure representing the two-photon Rabi splitting.
The one-photon QRM exhibits single-photon blockade, indicated by sub-Poissonian photon statistics.
The two-photon QRM exhibits single-photon blockade, despite a transmission profile similar to an empty cavity.
The one-photon QRM shows a suppressed transmission at the cavity frequency due to the absence of atomic excitation.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Formula (20), how does the addition of multiple qubits (increasing N) affect the critical coupling strength (g_col) required to reach the spectral collapse in the two-photon QRM?
choices: g_col remains constant regardless of N.
g_col decreases exponentially with increasing N.
